Name: Metaldehyde
Description: Metaldehyde is a member of the class of tetroxocanes that is 1,3,5,7-tetroxocane which carries four methyl groups at positions 2,4,6 and 8. It is a potent molluscicide and the active ingredient in most slug pellets used for crop protection. It has a role as a molluscicide and a fuel.

environmental_bioconcentrations.References: (1) Tomlin CDS, ed; The e-Pesticide Manual: a world compendium. Metaldehyde. 13th ed. PC CD-ROM, Version 3.0, 2003-04. Surrey, UK: British Crop Protection Council, (2003) (2) Meylan WM et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 18: 664-72 (1999) (3) Franke C et al; Chemosphere 29: 1501-14 (1994)
environmental_bioconcentrations.Value: An estimated BCF of 3.2 was calculated for metaldehyde(SRC), using a log Kow of 0.12(1) and a regression-derived equation(2). According to a classification scheme(3), this BCF suggests the potential for bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is low(SRC).

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) NITE; Chemical Risk Information Platform (CHRIP). Biodegradation and Bioconcentration. Tokyo, Japan: Natl Inst Tech Eval. Available at https://www.safe.nite.go.jp/english/db.html as of October 27, 2009. (2) USEPA; Reregistration Eligibility Decisions (REDs) Database on Metaldehyde (108-62-3). USEPA DOC NO. 0576 Available from the Database Query page at https://www.epa.gov/pesticides/reregistration/status.htm as of October 23, 2009. (3) Tomlin CDS, ed; The e-Pesticide Manual: a world compendium. Metaldehyde. 13th ed. PC CD-ROM, Version 3.0, 2003-04. Surrey, UK: British Crop Protection Council, (2003)
environmental_biodegradations.Value: AEROBIC: Metaldehyde, present at 100 mg/L, reached 0% of its theoretical BOD in 4 weeks using an activated sludge inoculum at 30 mg/L in the Japanese MITI test(1). Under aerobic conditions, the half-life of metaldehyde in soil has been reported as approximately two months(2). In soil, microbiological decomposition of metaldehyde to carbon dioxide and water occurs(3).

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) USEPA; Reregistration Eligibility Decisions (REDs) Database on Metaldehyde (108-62-3). USEPA DOC NO. 0576 Available from, as of October 23, 2009: https://www.epa.gov/pesticides/reregistration/status.htm
environmental_biodegradations.Value: ANAEROBIC: Under anaerobic conditions, the half-life of metaldehyde has been reported as greater than 200 days(1).

logP.References: Tomlin CDS, ed; The e-Pesticide Manual: a world compendium. Metaldehyde. 13th ed. PC CD-ROM, Version 3.0, 2003-04. Surrey, UK: British Crop Protection Council, (2003)

mechanism_of_action.References: IPCS; Poisons Information Monograph 332: Metaldehyde (June, 1990). Available from, as of October 9, 2009: https://www.inchem.org/pages/pims.html
mechanism_of_action.Value: The toxicologically active substance in metaldehyde intoxication is mainly the degradation product acetaldehyde, which is formed at a low pH in the stomach.  Other toxic products are probably also formed.  Acetaldehyde acts as a releasing factor for 5-hydroxytryptamine (5-HT) and noradrenaline (NA).  It also competitively inhibits biogenic amine oxidation which, in turn, decreases 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA), a metabolite of 5-HT by competitively inhibiting 5-HT-oxidation.  Acetaldehyde also increases monoamine oxidase activity and decreases central serotonin levels ...

mechanism_of_action.References: IPCS; Poisons Information Monograph 332: Metaldehyde (June, 1990). Available from, as of October 9, 2009: https://www.inchem.org/pages/pims.html
mechanism_of_action.Value: Its pesticidal action is due to contact with the foot of the mollusk, making it torpid and increasing the secretion of mucus leading to dehydration.

soil_absorption_mobility.References: (1) Tomlin CDS, ed; The e-Pesticide Manual: a world compendium. Metaldehyde. 13th ed. PC CD-ROM, Version 3.0, 2003-04. Surrey, UK: British Crop Protection Council, (2003) (2) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 17-28 (1983)
soil_absorption_mobility.Value: The Koc of metaldehye is measured as 240(1). According to a classification scheme(2), this Koc value suggests that metaldehyde is expected to have moderate mobility in soil.
